FRIDAY, September 2S, 1927.

At meeting of the friends of the Adminlstra-
ton, held at the house of Joshua Hutton, on Mon
dav the oath inst. Robert Porter was appointed
Chairman and John L. Gilpin Secretary. on mo-
ton it was -,


RESOLVED, unanimously. that this meeting cordial
ly approve the nomination OF h. JOHNS, Jh as
candidate for Congress- made at Dover, on iaes-
day the 18th inst. as well as the County tioke'
agreed upon at Clark's Corner on the 18th inst.
and that we will use all fair and honorable means to
insure the success of said ticket at the ensuing
election.


Resolued, That we approve the nomination at
New Castle. Of James Mccullough, (FarIner) to
sunply the place of James Booth. resigned, as a
candidate for the legislature Of this state.


Resolyed, That the following persons be appoint
ed committee Of vigilance. and be requested 10 use
all diligence, to induce persons III favor oi ''e au-
mnistration, to attend at the polls.

AGENTS.

At large and respectable meeting OF the friends
of the present Administration of the General Gov
ernment held at Blackbird, on Thursday goth OF
September, Major WILLIAM ROTHWELL was
called TO the char, and BENJAMIN CAULk ap-
pointed Secretary.


The proceedings Of the meeting at Clark's corner
being read, the following resolutions were unanl-
mousy adopted.


Resolved That in the opinion ofths meeting, the
Administration of the General Government is per-
fecty clear of all the charges of bargain and corrup-
tion which the leaders of the Opposition have en-.
deavored to fix upon it.


Resolved, that we highly approve OF the nonlna-
tion made by the Conferees at Dover, and that we
will use all honorable mems to insure the election OF
KENsEy JOHNS, JR. Esq. the Congressional Candi-
date nominated


Resolved, that we approve OF the proceedings CT
the meeting at Clars corner, and that we Will give
our firm and undivided support to the county ticket
there formed.


Resolved, that committee OF vigilance be ap-
pointed by the chairman and they are requested to
TO use all honorable means best calculated TO support
the present Administration.


Resolved. that the proceedings of this meeting be
published in the papers in this county friendly to
th, present Administration of theGeneral Govern
ment. -


w. RoTHwELL, Chairman.
BsNJ.m1N CAuIE. SeC'y.
APPOQUINIMiNK HUNDRED.

At meeting of the friends OF the Administration
in Brandywne Hundred, at the Blue Ball lnn. on
Saturday, the 22nd September, 1927, pursuant to
the public notice, COLONEL THOMAS KOBlNSs'N
was called to the chair, and William M1Cauiey aP-
pointed secretary. when the following resolutions
were unanimously adopted: :


Resolued, That we approve OF the nomination OF
KENSEY JOHNS, Jatnr. Esq. for Representative
to Congress That we will render him our united
and cordial support and that we recommend nm TO
the friends of order and good government as cltl-
zen worthy of their support and confidence. =,


Resolued, That we approve OF the County nichet
formed by the Administration meeting lat Clark $
Corner) and that we will all fair and honorable
means to promote its success.


Resolved, That the following persons be COM
mittee of vigilance to watch over the interests OF
the constitution and the people for this Hundred
to wit Colonel Thomas Robinson, William Long,
John b. Bains, Cunning Bedford, William houson'
Thomas Can, Samuel Gaibreath, William McCaui-
lev, Charles Dupont, John Bird, John Forwood'

Pirate Mich'gan.--Wc have conversed WIN
passenyeroa board OF the steam boat IRON Albany
yesterday, who left Niagara Falls on last oa.uruay
evening. He stated that the "conaemneu sessa,
got loose from her moorings little after the appoint
ed time, andwas proceeding iavourably until within
about mile Of the edge Of the fall, when she struck
against rock with great violence, and carried away
both of her masts After this she tossed and rolled
about violently in the rapids Zone of the larger AMI
mails. the buffalo made complete and safe es-
cape rom her, and was finally prccp;ated over the
great fall at the Horseshoe. The sight IS stated TO
have been very interesting one, and was viewed
ny an immense number OF spectators.


Com. ,qdv.

CONDITIONS.

lie death of John Webb, David Morrow, John Harris
nry Lewis, David Hunt, and Edward Lindsey; 81,
li'iamen who were condemned to die, the sentenc,
proved by Major Gen. JACKSON, and by his order thu
loe six shot,
o did you hear that pIantve cry,
Borne on the southern breezep
Saw you John Harris, earnest pray
For mercy, on his knees
Low to tli e earth he bent, and prayd
For pardon from his chief;
But to his earnest prayer for life
jackson alas was deaf.
g. s'Spare me'-he said" meant no wrong
My heart was always true
" First for my Country's cause it beat,
"And next, great Chief, for you.
"We thought our time of service out
"-Thought it our right to go:
"We meant to violate no law;
"Nor w,sl,'d to shun the foe.
sour officers declared that we
+" Had but three months to stay;
/" We Sc we'd those three months faithfully,
"UP to the latest day.
'.No one suspects intended wrong;
" The Judgment only erred;
SIN such u case, o noble Chief,
"Let mercy's voice be heard.
aAt home an aged mother waits
"To clasp her only son;
ga wife, and nine small children
"Ths arm depend upon.
"Cut me not off from those dear ties.
''Nor send me to my doom,
0 'tls dreadful thing to die,


Sand moulder in the tomb!
"Sure mercy is a noble gem


"On every Chieftans brow;
"More sparkling than dadem:
90! exercise il now"
twas all in vain, John Harris prayr,
'Tis past the SOUPS belief!
Hard as the flint was Jackson's heart:
lie would not grant relief.
He nrder'd Harris out to die,


And five poor fellows more
Young gallant men in prime of life
10 welter in their gore!
Methnks hear the muff1ed drum,
And see the column move;
--Lo here they come How sad their looks
Farewell to life and love!
See six black coffins rang'd along,


Six graves before them made;
Webb, Lindsey. Harriss, Lewis, Hunt,
And Morrow kneeled and prayed.
They kneepd and pray'd, and thought of LOVE,
And ali its dear delights.
The deadly tubes are levelled now


The scene my soul affrignts
Sure lie will spare Sure Jackson yet


Will all reprievc but one
o harl those shrieks that cry of death
Th, dreadful deed is done
All six militia men were shot;


AND o it seems to me;
A dreadful deei--a bloody act


Of needless craety
MOURNFUL TRAGEDY.

assortment of Fall Goods, such as Cloths, Cassi-
meres Flannells Blankets, Sattinetts, Worsted, &C.
which he will sell at reduced prices.


Any quantity of wool and feathers will be taken
ln and Goods gwen in exchange at fair market
nrico at his Store. No. 1O1, Market-Sreet.

jealous. and undivided support %! the Friends OF

,4,pfid CALAMITY. u.-Three mef, father and two
sons, named Saul. were killed On the 9TH instant,
near Columbus. in Ohio, in attempting to descend
into we'll, filled with fire damp. The particulars
as they have been reIatet, to us. were as folowsi
They had been engaged in digging the well, anu
had decended twenty feet II was o5served' the
night before, that, on coming out. the workifiert
appeared unusually pale On returning to the sVuik
Yesterday morning, brother lnaw of the young
Sauls, first attempted to descend, but experienced
so much distress before he reached the buttor1 that
1 he requested to BIZ drawn up. One OF tile yadng
men then got into the bucket, and was let down
about half when he fell to the bottom Of the syell


His brother Immediately attempted to descend to
his relief, but likewise fell belore reaching the bots
torn. The father then, contrary to the reifohz
trance of those about him, insisted On being ct
down he had descended about half way, when ne
called out to be drawn up again. butt before ne feaehS
ed the top, he also pitched out and fell dead upon
his dead sons Means were Immediately taKeii to
recover the dead bodies and attempts were made 10
resus scitate them, but vitality was wholly extinct.

full articles.headline: APPOQUINIMiNK HUNDRED.
full articles.article:
At large and respectable meeting OF the friends
of the present Administration of the General Gov
ernment held at Blackbird, on Thursday goth OF
September, Major WILLIAM ROTHWELL was
called TO the char, and BENJAMIN CAULk ap-
pointed Secretary.


The proceedings Of the meeting at Clark's corner
being read, the following resolutions were unanl-
mousy adopted.


Resolved That in the opinion ofths meeting, the
Administration of the General Government is per-
fecty clear of all the charges of bargain and corrup-
tion which the leaders of the Opposition have en-.
deavored to fix upon it.


Resolved, that we highly approve OF the nonlna-
tion made by the Conferees at Dover, and that we
will use all honorable mems to insure the election OF
KENsEy JOHNS, JR. Esq. the Congressional Candi-
date nominated


Resolved, that we approve OF the proceedings CT
the meeting at Clars corner, and that we Will give
our firm and undivided support to the county ticket
there formed.


Resolved, that committee OF vigilance be ap-
pointed by the chairman and they are requested to
TO use all honorable means best calculated TO support
the present Administration.


Resolved. that the proceedings of this meeting be
published in the papers in this county friendly to
th, present Administration of theGeneral Govern
ment. -


w. RoTHwELL, Chairman.
BsNJ.m1N CAuIE. SeC'y.

full articles.headline:
BENJAMIN CAuLg, Sec'y.

BRANDY WINE.
full articles.article:
At meeting of the friends OF the Administration
in Brandywne Hundred, at the Blue Ball lnn. on
Saturday, the 22nd September, 1927, pursuant to
the public notice, COLONEL THOMAS KOBlNSs'N
was called to the chair, and William M1Cauiey aP-
pointed secretary. when the following resolutions
were unanimously adopted: :


Resolued, That we approve OF the nomination OF
KENSEY JOHNS, Jatnr. Esq. for Representative
to Congress That we will render him our united
and cordial support and that we recommend nm TO
the friends of order and good government as cltl-
zen worthy of their support and confidence. =,


Resolued, That we approve OF the County nichet
formed by the Administration meeting lat Clark $
Corner) and that we will all fair and honorable
means to promote its success.


Resolved, That the following persons be COM
mittee of vigilance to watch over the interests OF
the constitution and the people for this Hundred
to wit Colonel Thomas Robinson, William Long,
John b. Bains, Cunning Bedford, William houson'
Thomas Can, Samuel Gaibreath, William McCaui-
lev, Charles Dupont, John Bird, John Forwood'

full articles.headline: New Y oRK, Sept. l3.
full articles.article:
Pirate Mich'gan.--Wc have conversed WIN
passenyeroa board OF the steam boat IRON Albany
yesterday, who left Niagara Falls on last oa.uruay
evening. He stated that the "conaemneu sessa,
got loose from her moorings little after the appoint
ed time, andwas proceeding iavourably until within
about mile Of the edge Of the fall, when she struck
against rock with great violence, and carried away
both of her masts After this she tossed and rolled
about violently in the rapids Zone of the larger AMI
mails. the buffalo made complete and safe es-
cape rom her, and was finally prccp;ated over the
great fall at the Horseshoe. The sight IS stated TO
have been very interesting one, and was viewed
ny an immense number OF spectators.


Com. ,qdv.

full articles.headline: MOURNFUL TRAGEDY.
full articles.article:
lie death of John Webb, David Morrow, John Harris
nry Lewis, David Hunt, and Edward Lindsey; 81,
li'iamen who were condemned to die, the sentenc,
proved by Major Gen. JACKSON, and by his order thu
loe six shot,
o did you hear that pIantve cry,
Borne on the southern breezep
Saw you John Harris, earnest pray
For mercy, on his knees
Low to tli e earth he bent, and prayd
For pardon from his chief;
But to his earnest prayer for life
jackson alas was deaf.
g. s'Spare me'-he said" meant no wrong
My heart was always true
" First for my Country's cause it beat,
"And next, great Chief, for you.
"We thought our time of service out
"-Thought it our right to go:
"We meant to violate no law;
"Nor w,sl,'d to shun the foe.
sour officers declared that we
+" Had but three months to stay;
/" We Sc we'd those three months faithfully,
"UP to the latest day.
'.No one suspects intended wrong;
" The Judgment only erred;
SIN such u case, o noble Chief,
"Let mercy's voice be heard.
aAt home an aged mother waits
"To clasp her only son;
ga wife, and nine small children
"Ths arm depend upon.
"Cut me not off from those dear ties.
''Nor send me to my doom,
0 'tls dreadful thing to die,


Sand moulder in the tomb!
"Sure mercy is a noble gem


"On every Chieftans brow;
"More sparkling than dadem:
90! exercise il now"
twas all in vain, John Harris prayr,
'Tis past the SOUPS belief!
Hard as the flint was Jackson's heart:
lie would not grant relief.
He nrder'd Harris out to die,


And five poor fellows more
Young gallant men in prime of life
10 welter in their gore!
Methnks hear the muff1ed drum,
And see the column move;
--Lo here they come How sad their looks
Farewell to life and love!
See six black coffins rang'd along,


Six graves before them made;
Webb, Lindsey. Harriss, Lewis, Hunt,
And Morrow kneeled and prayed.
They kneepd and pray'd, and thought of LOVE,
And ali its dear delights.
The deadly tubes are levelled now


The scene my soul affrignts
Sure lie will spare Sure Jackson yet


Will all reprievc but one
o harl those shrieks that cry of death
Th, dreadful deed is done
All six militia men were shot;


AND o it seems to me;
A dreadful deei--a bloody act


Of needless craety

ply the vacancy in the County ticket nceasioned

committee. viz Evan Thomas, CUrheus u. Biahets

be filed with the name OF James Di'Cuitough Far
mer, and he is hereby recommended to the h.n.
jealous. and undivided support %! the Friends OF
the Administration Of the General Government in
New Castle County at the ensuing General Eleca
ton. .

tee of Vigilance ior New Castle Hundred, who Will

Wiley, esq. Joseph Sawyer, VIM. Guthrie, samuel

Turner. -,

.ooDo;oa.-A


,4,pfid CALAMITY. u.-Three mef, father and two
sons, named Saul. were killed On the 9TH instant,
near Columbus. in Ohio, in attempting to descend
into we'll, filled with fire damp. The particulars
as they have been reIatet, to us. were as folowsi
They had been engaged in digging the well, anu
had decended twenty feet II was o5served' the
night before, that, on coming out. the workifiert
appeared unusually pale On returning to the sVuik
Yesterday morning, brother lnaw of the young
Sauls, first attempted to descend, but experienced
so much distress before he reached the buttor1 that
1 he requested to BIZ drawn up. One OF tile yadng
men then got into the bucket, and was let down
about half when he fell to the bottom Of the syell


His brother Immediately attempted to descend to
his relief, but likewise fell belore reaching the bots
torn. The father then, contrary to the reifohz
trance of those about him, insisted On being ct
down he had descended about half way, when ne
called out to be drawn up again. butt before ne feaehS
ed the top, he also pitched out and fell dead upon
his dead sons Means were Immediately taKeii to
recover the dead bodies and attempts were made 10
resus scitate them, but vitality was wholly extinct.


IWest Statesman,
